And as for your personality, as you call it—well, you know, I think you are absolutely charming. But you are not a work of art. You have the most wonderful smile, and the most delightful wit, and a perfectly ingenuous nature. But a work of art can never be anything more, or anything different, than a work of art." "I am glad you appreciate me, Harry," said Basil, smiling. "But I must say I think it is a very erroneous standard of measurement." "On the contrary," continued Lord Henry, "it is the standard of all measurement. It is the measure of the most beautiful things. I know there are those who claim that the sense of beauty is merely transient, an accident of mood, an excuse for the emotion of the moment. I deny it. Beauty is eternal. It is the key to all art, and though I am not a religious man, it is the secret of the most religious of all experiences. Beauty is nature's antithesis of death. And why should man desire to give it any other name? There are mediocrities who adopt strange terms—terms distinguished by hideousness, and want of meaning—to speak of modes of beauty. They deny that beauty can be expressed by form and colour. It is not so. These are the precise means by which man seeks to translate into a language that he can comprehend his conception of the beautiful." "How well you defend an error, Harry!" cried Basil. "But the error, my dear Basil, is yours," answered Lord Henry, smiling. "You remember that saying of ours about the difference between labour and success? Indeed, it is curious how this thing happens. Each of us has his own secret griefs, which the world knows nothing of. It is not the melodramas of passion, but the harmonies of colour, for which the world is waiting. We in our madness have troubled ourselves with losses and gains, with the vulgar, wearisome pomp of pleasure and pain. We have forgotten the true reason of life. We have forgotten that life itself is an art, and that the merest breath of it is divine. Is it not wonderful that, in our mad rush after money, position, fame, or power, we have not left the space for a single human passion to be really lived out in? We suppress everything. When we forget the value of our own souls, we wander about in a meaningless world, and our whole being is a kind of horror. And it is this horror, this grotesque and dreadful tragedy of a soulless existence, that is the one thing that art never shows us, and that photography cannot fix.
